job_title: Applications Software Developer in Oxford, OH
pros:
Come here if you want to do the following...

> work-life balance (actually more life than work).
> ok tech stack and the push to move to the cloud (opportunities to learn and grow in these areas are a plus but you should motivate yourself to do things otherwise you will see none of that).
> Management willing to invest in training efforts and provide some time for personal development (Having said that these opportunities also require self-motivation and power through all the cons which keep demotivating you ).
> ITS management is generally supportive and good people (But they are constrained by the ridiculous HR).
cons:
Stay absolutely away if you are expecting below...

> No Competitive pay (this is a public-funded university so can't expect much)
> Not so friendly HR policies (oftentimes slow, inconsistent, rigid, and detrimental to the average worker and the IT department as a whole).
> Internal promotions (competitive hiring at each level, you need to apply to get promoted and I am not saying this is bad but I feel like people should be rewarded for merit not performing well in 2 hours interviews).
> Administrative staff = second class employee compared to academic staff (Obvious right university is students and professor who cares about janitors, librarians, food service staff, IT staff e.t.c.)

Above creates an environment of people joining and leaving as expectations are not met. It is painful to write the cons as someone who has gone through the above but I really expect these things to change and the IT department to flourish.

job_title: Building and Grounds Assistant in Oxford, OH
pros:
Health insurance is pretty good.

Tuition waiver.
cons:
They will work you into the ground for $13/hr.

They do not honor past raises if the pay tier of a position changes. (My position of 6 years at the time was elevated from E1 to E2 and I lost 6 years' worth of raises because my current pay was under the new pay minimum. I now make as much as a new employee despite the time I have put in.)

There is a culture of nepotism. You will only get promoted if you know someone. If you put your years in you will get considered for a job first, but that is as far as it goes.

The union is useless.

Inter-department communication is negligible.

Students are treated like royalty and can do anything they want without any kind of repercussion, including property damage, theft, and drug use.

Miami only cares about their image, so they will let things slide as long as it stays out of the public eye. All of the sexual assaults that happen on campus weekly are unpunished, but a frat makes the news for hazing and it's shut down.

pros: The faculty are exceptional - they're among the best I've worked with in more than 20 years in higher education.
cons:
I've never heard a faculty member say anything good about the current provost - many are just waiting for him to leave and see it as inevitable. There's a lot of micromanagement and miscommunication across the board and a total leadership vacuum in my division. In all of our internal conversations about programming, not once has ensuring that students have a good learning experience ever been mentioned. We seem to just design things around our senior leadership or our director's whims, and they're more focused on building their own careers than creating an equitable team environment or high-quality courses.

Many staff are in positions where they're expected to do work above their title/pay grade or even do work that's not a part of their position at all. At the same time, there's absolutely no accountability, so some people hide out and do little to no work. I personally did not have any sort of performance review in the 2 years I was on the job.

Many female staff and faculty have said that their voices aren't heard - and when women are in leadership positions, they're often sidelined or ignored. At the same time, I've seen white cisgender men who are not qualified for a management position either be promoted into one or remain in one despite the fact that they can't competently do the job. The dirty secret is that Miami still very much feels like an old boys club.

job_title: Event Production Team Crew Leader in Oxford, OH
pros: Miami University offers a lot of student employment in all areas of the University including Dining, Building Managing, Office work, etc. My area is in Event Production and A/V support. Generally professional staff here is on your side, very flexible with hours, and pretty relaxed when it comes to expectations. It's a great spot to learn leadership skills (in my position I oversee other students).
cons: HR at Miami isn't super great or easy to work with. Up until recently I was the most experienced employee in my leadership position, but was making less than newer and less experienced coworkers and was making only 30 cents more than the students I oversee despite having the higher expectations of delegating and leading a team as well as a deeper knowledge and understanding of the systems we use. We asked HR to fix the wage compression that I and one other employee were facing, and they said it wasn't something they can handle (yes they can). There are more lucrative opportunities elsewhere, but this job offers an ease into responsiblity

pros:
Relaxed environment, and lots of room to achieve and stand out if you put forth the effort. You can really drive your own growth and get references as a developer from both clients and other devs. 

I would recommend Miami to someone who is motivated, because you can complete all your project work and take time to learn new tech all within your 40 hour week, as long as you are focused. I personally think this is a great starting point for a career as a developer. You also get to work with a wide range of tech if you want to.
cons:
In order to experience the growth, you have to be and stay motivated. It is an environment that is very easy to get complacent in. It's probably too relaxed but I think that's a byproduct of recent structural changes. Currently (mid 2016) there are many recently hired engineers in IT services. 

The college and the town the college are in will pretty much have to be your life if you're not from the area. If you have to commute, you will either live in the middle of nowhere, or you will be have a very long commute. They make it sound like they are close to Cincinnati, but it's really about a 40 min drive to Cincy suburbs from the college. 

Pay is also not competitive here. If Salary is your primary motivation, this will not be the place for you.

pros: I have been asking myself this sense I came and still do not have answer. If you have children the eventual potential to attend the university for free seems to attract people.
cons:
- I am currently employed is as a staff/faculty member. I have worked here for  year now. The department I am in has an incredibly high turnover  rate. Additionally, the leadership team is not at all interested in the actual day-to-day operations. There is general incompetence, mismanagement, and a top down attitude of blatant misogyny that I have never experienced until I came to work here. A lot of people are deeply connected to this university as they were former students. The preoccupation with legacy status is entrenched-so if you are from out of town prepared to be annoyed with the general since of entitlement that pervades this campus. Money, at least in this department, is a serious issue so much so that the contract I was just extended was for a 9 month instead of a year long contract. Never mind the fact that they have been dumping work on the already thin on the ground staff. 
They will sell you on the "opportunities to advance" but the reality is that once you are here it is very difficult to move out of a role or to receive significant increase in pay unless you know someone who knows someone because nepotism is also a part of the culture which explains some of the top down problems we currently have.

pros: Some faculty are well-educated, smart and care about their students. The sudents are, for the most, fun to work with, although it depends on which program they're in. It has a pretty main campus.
cons: The Middletown campus is about to close according to what I am seeing and hearing. There has been no official announcment, but Middletown VIPs are moving into positions in Hamilton and obviously dislodging Hamiton folks to do so. Very troubling is that one of the jobs being saved is that of the Provost's husband.  This is a good example of how Miami functions below the student service level. It is corrupt in the favoritism that it shows spouses and  clearly incompetent instructors who have poliltical value. My recommendation is look elsewhere. If Middletown collapese, the folks who brought it down will be in place in Hamilton. How long will that last. When Hamilton goes, Miami will be severely threatened as a state school. Also, its debt is way beyond where it should be, Signs of a struggle to keep Miami functioning are everywhere.

job_title: Rapid Prototyping Laboratory Manager in Oxford, OH
pros: Great work environment and amazing boss. As an Engineer at Miami, I loved the machinese in the Engineering Building. They were a part of my success, and let's face it, they're like big (albeit dangerous) toys for adults. To this extent, the Rapid Prototyping Lab had the best machines in the building. 3D Printer and Scanner, Automated Micro-Mill, Laser Cutter, etc. However, while these machines aren't meant to be played with, I couldn't help but enjoy helping other people complete their projects with them, but I guess that's called being passionate about your job? Anyway, most of the time the lab is quiet because people don't always need something to be laser cut or printed in 3D, so it was great to do homework while working. Perfect use of my time and I was more than happy to do it.
cons: This job does require technical skills and it is on the school's salary, so don't expect to be paid as much. That kinda becomes balanced when you look at the time you have to complete homework and other responsibilities in the lab though, so it's not a big deal.

pros: They work with you on your schedule if you are in enrolled at the university. You get a retirement fund no matter if you are full time or part time, which can be good or bad depending on how you view it. The co-workers at your own level are great, but the higher up they go, the worse they get.
cons: Where do I start.. They treat everyone terrible. The managers are hypocrites who refuse to follow the policies they put in place for everyone else. They are routinely understaffed and then refuse to help out when the building begins to struggle to keep up with customer service demands. They don't care if you get a break but they make sure to get theirs and to take extra time. They expect too much for the small wage they pay.

pros: My colleagues are friendly.  Miami is hugely successful in recruiting rich Chinese kids, which is beneficial for university finances.
cons:
Miami is very image-focused, but only as far as advertising brochures are concerned.  There is little concern over academic quality (maybe my idea of "research-active" is just different from theirs) of faculty; they seem only to care about the students' teaching evaluations.  Classes seem "dumbed-down"; grade inflation is rampant.  

It is clear to me that my department hired me based on research credentials, while the University was just looking for a popular teacher.

pros: Smart motivated hard working faculty, pleasant working environment, good work-life balance. Good overall reputation and long outstanding history for the institution. Despite cutbacks in budgets, outstanding overall benefits.
cons: As in most higher-ed environments, budgetary concerns can be onerous and sometimes feel like the only factor driving decisions. All faculty and staff understand budget is important and I sincerely believe people do not purposely waste money and valuable resources, but are sometimes made to feel like they do by higher administration. When money becomes the sole focus of decisions, many bad decisions result and negatively impact the true mission of educating students.

pros:
Great flexibility and freedom to do what I needed to do. Got to work with the mentality of doing things now and apologizing later if need be. I could wear whatever I wanted to work, book travel as needed, and really just get things done.

Also, there is a huge amount of vacation time and sick time. Retirement benefits are fantastic. You can also go to the health center on campus and not have to pay a copay!
cons:
So many admins are employed here unnecessarily. Most of them sit on Facebook all day but won't ever be fired because seniority plays a factor here.

Also, most departments were not like mine. This negatively impacted me because I was constantly working with Debbie Downers in other departments.

review_title: Great People. Good University. Not an accessible town
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Oxford, OH
pros:
Great bunch of people and you can get a good experience and exposure. Most of the departments give assistantship/funding/aid to students (especially Graduate students). Coursework is not very strenuous, yet get to learn a lot.
Great working environment, as everyone is helpful and social.
cons:
The place is little cut-off from other cities. Buses go to other towns and cities, but timings and locations are not really convenient. The town looks deserted during summer and winter vacations. The local (intra-oxford) bus service used to be good till 2013, but this year it has been very poor.
Career fair has very few choices (sometimes only 1 or 2) for international graduate students in Engineering, Science & Technology streams.

review_title: "Miami University is the best college in Ohio hands down!"
pros: I love Miami Univiersity, great place to go to school and work.  I love Miami its such a great school because of the education and the beautiful campus.  The campus is one of the best in the United States and is even one of the  "public ivys".  The business school is great, one of the best in the country (I believe it is ranked 24th in undergraduate business schools).  I am a marketing major and love my classes and professors.  I also love my job working at an on-campus dining hall.  They pay is good, and the flexibility is unbeatable.  Together this makes Miami a top notch University.
cons: Sometimes the work is boring.

review_title: Great Colleagues... too many upper management positions
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Middletown, OH
pros:
Many of the people working at Miami are smart, kind and hard working.
Decent benefit package
cons: Business model at the expense of many other areas and disciplines. Unfair faculty ranking system where many are underpaid yet expected to work and do a lot. Lack of acknowledgement or reward for hard work above and beyond. Many of the deans seem to have a lack of vision and only focus on numbers. Hiring and retaining policy seems fluid and I know of too many instances where people are hired because of a spouse, or former student etc. and others are not. Budgets are continually cut from departments, staff who do a lot of work yet there seems to be ongoing postings for upper management types. There is the bloat that should be trimmed.

pros: A public Ivy university, but at what cost...
cons:
These are the Worst people I’ve ever met! 
PLEASE don’t apply or accept a position here! I’ve never been more dehumanized, overworked, and underpaid in my career. 
Over the summer, half the professional staff quits because the environment is SO toxic, and they immediately attribute it to “natural attrition.” Miami culture is hyperaggressive, to the degree that students don’t even want to go to college here and many graduate in 3 years or less. 
Student body are bratty, rich kids who have never been told “no” a day in their lives, and the parents now expect others to teach them to be decent people. 
When students don’t get their way, they report you (full-time, pro staff) to their supervisors because they know their daddies will make a phone call and solve any problem they’re experiencing. 
Terrible Job. Terrible Students. Terrible Culture = NOT Worth having Miami on your resume!!!!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Bernard, OH
pros: Working for one of the dining halls was a great experience. The pay was the highest of any student workers on campus at the time, the hours were very flexible in terms of scheduling around classes, and there was opportunity to be promoted to manager position if you wanted to put in the work. Really easy work, for decent pay. If you are a go-with-the-flow and get your work done kind of person, it's a good place to be.
cons: Not great if you don't like working with people. Teamwork and customer service required no matter where you were placed for that shift. Lots of walking/lifting/standing, although the shifts were short. Could get stressful on days when there were big events and lots of people coming in to eat.

pros: State retirement plan, good benefits package, very competitive vacation and sick time accrual, lots of opportunity for personal and job-related growth. The students are always the number one priority.
cons: The culture at Miami can, at times, be from upper management down, and does not always take in consideration the front-line staff of an operation. Additionally, the overwhelming amount of union employees can make it difficult to hire the right person for a job.

pros: Miami University is a great employer in the Ohio area. Absolutely would suggest to anyone to work for MU, at any level, be it in the administration or in the classroom.
cons: I don't have many bad things to say about Miami University. The only problem is the location, which is in the middle of nowhere in Ohio. The town around it, Oxford, is a classic college town, and you have to like that kind of area

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor/Visiting Instructor in Oxford, OH
pros: Generally on your own and able to create your own lesson plans.
cons:
*Incredibly low pay for a professional teaching position - less than a McDonald's manager. Visiting positions are paid the same regardless of experience or expertise.  ($32,000 for Visiting Instructors and $43,000 for visiting asst. professors annually in 2017 - NOT what Glassdoor says)
*Isolated location surrounded by farms and stuck in a pizza. burger college town (doesn't even have a movie theater) every restaurant is filled with students, other options are 30-40 minutes away 
*University has a huge budget for entertaining the students (events, sports, free meals, etc...) but keeps salaries low.  They are proud that they are 'lean' - but the staff and faculty are paying for it with a low quality of life. 
*The students are generally from upper middle-class families and tend to expect special treatment and spoon-feeding. Entitled and quick to complain if anything doesn't favor them. 
*No training for safety / intruders, most training focused on anything the college could be held liable for. 
* Some departments have very few long term, full-time positions and just keep Visiting staff on the hook with promises that there 'could be' permanent positions in the future. After 5 years, they 'let you go', no matter how much you have contributed.

pros: People are great, schedule is somewhat flexible, and is easy to manage along with school and other obligations that students have. Hiring process was easy for experienced interviewees.
cons: Cutting back on staff and shifts with little to no explanation. I got back and found out that I was only authorized to be a substitute guide since they had a "full" schedule.

pros: this office is great! They make sure that you feel included in everything and guarantee that the hours will work with your schedule.
cons: There are some times when the desk can get very busy, like at the beginning of the semester. The office also handles some sensitive information so keeping that on the DL can be difficult at times!

pros: Exposure to many technologies, great benefits, and leniency in getting time off. It's a college town, so it's busy in the 9 months out of the year.
cons: There was a lot of positive momentum in the IT division until 2009. The politics and love of red tape got way out of control and now most things move at a snail's pace or not done at all.

pros: Great people and awesome residents. The dining room has great food and the facility is beautiful. Easy to get to as well.
cons: The pay rates are pretty poor.  If you have a second job, it's OK to help supplement your income, but they don't like to pay you for your overtime. You end up working your tail off for little money.

cons: Nothing. Everything is awesome.

review_title: Toxic working environment with poor benefits
pros: I really have nothing good to say about this place, and I'm happy that I no longer work here.
cons: Miami is known for being one of the most "efficient" higher-ed institutes, which, upon a closer look, simply means you get minimal pay while working extra long hours. The employee benefits are the bare minimum, not to mention that the upper admins will take every opportunity to make budget cuts. COVID-19 is a good test stone that revealed how financially fragile this university actually is, and how little the admins care about the well-beings of its employers. Long story short, it is a community college with a fancy top public school shell.

pros: The environment is very collaborative and encouraging. Faculty and staff tend to be rather positive and great to work with. Students are generally - though not always - motivated and attentive.
cons: One negative about teaching low level courses at a university is that students need support as they become more independent. There are students who don't yet know how to communicate professionally with faculty or manage their time well, and the result can make your job harder.

pros: Free school along with great research and teaching experience along with an amazing faculty that are always helpful and give great guidance for future endeavors.
cons: Just like any graduate assistant the pay is lower compared to a full time job but that happens for every graduate assistant.  Besides that there is no real con.
